topic.title: Creating a load balancer for a MySQL cluster

body.p: This topic describes how to create a load balancer for a MySQL cluster from the command line, and how to use a load balancer in an application.

A load balancer is an object that exposes a VIP (Virtual IP address) endpoint to applications, and manages pools (logical sets of devices, such as web servers, that you group together to receive and process traffic), listeners (processes that monitor connections to endpoints), and members (applications running on the backend server).

section.title: Connect to your database and set up a MySQL cluster

ol.li: Log in to the installer node for your HPE Helion OpenStack environment and source the service.osrc file: . service.osrc

Use the following trove cluster-create command to create a 3 instance mysql cluster : trove cluster-create test-mysql-cluster mysql-cluster 5.5 --instance flavor=2,volume=2,nic='net-id=<uuid-of-private-subnet>' --instance flavor=2,volume=2,nic='net-id=<uuid-of-private-subnet>' --instance flavor=2,volume=2,nic='net-id=<uuid-of-private-subnet>'

section.title: Create a load balancer with Neutron 2.0

ol.li: Use the following Neutron command to create a load balancer: neutron lbaas-loadbalancer-create --name lb-mysql-cluster private-subnet
Use the following Neutron command to create a Listener: neutron lbaas-listener-create --loadbalancer lb-mysql-cluster --protocol TCP --protocol-port 3306 --name listener-mysql-cluster
Use the following Neutron command to create a Pool: neutron lbaas-pool-create --lb-algorithm ROUND_ROBIN --listener listener-mysql-cluster --protocol TCP --name pool-mysql-cluster

section.title: Create a load balancer with Neutron 1.0

ol.li: Use the following Neutron command to create a Pool: neutron lb-pool-create --lb-method ROUND_ROBIN --name pool-mysql-cluster --protocol TCP --subnet-id <uuid-of-private-subnet>
Use the following Neutron command to create a Virtual IP (VIP): neutron lb-vip-create --name lb-mysql-cluster --protocol-port 3306 --protocol TCP --subnet-id <uuid-of-private-subnet>

section.title: Create members using Neutron v2
section.p: Use the following command, with IP addresses from the cluster-show command above, to create members using Neutron v2:
section.codeblock: neutron lbaas-member-create --subnet private-subnet --address <mysql-cluster-member-1-ip> --protocol-port 3306 pool-mysql-cluster neutron lbaas-member-create --subnet private-subnet --address <mysql-cluster-member-2-ip> --protocol-port 3306 pool-mysql-cluster neutron lbaas-member-create --subnet private-subnet --address <mysql-cluster-member-3-ip> --protocol-port 3306 pool-mysql-cluster

section.title: Create members using Neutron v1
section.p: Use the following command, with IP addresses from the cluster-show command above, to create members using Neutron v1:
section.codeblock: neutron lb-member-create --address <mysql-cluster-member-1-ip> --protocol-port 3306 pool-mysql-cluster neutron lb-member-create --address <mysql-cluster-member-2-ip> --protocol-port 3306 pool-mysql-cluster neutron lb-member-create --address <mysql-cluster-member-3-ip> --protocol-port 3306 pool-mysql-cluster
